replication_study.hypothesis: In countries classified as strong democracies (Polity IV ≥ 9), higher economic-policy polarization – operationalised as the standard deviation of citizens’ answers to the “government responsibility” (GOV) question in the World Values Survey – is associated with a smaller share of government consumption in total final consumption.

data_plan.source_type: Cross-country dataset derived from the World Values Survey merged with World Bank national-accounts statistics.
data_plan.wave_or_subset: WVS Waves 5–7, aggregated to a single 2010 country observation; analysis optionally excludes Wave 7 (see code flag).
data_plan.unit_of_analysis: Country (one row per country, year fixed at 2010).
data_plan.access_details: File is provided in /app/data under the present project; no external download required.

qualification.explanation: The replication dataset is constructed from the same primary sources as the original study (WVS & World Bank) but represents a newly built cross-section that was not used in the published analyses, therefore providing an independent sample while maintaining conceptual fidelity.
qualification.similarity_to_original:
• Uses the same survey instrument (World Values Survey) to compute the key polarization measure ‘sd_gov’ (post_registration.json → “Polarization calculated ... GOV question”).
• Retains identical outcome variable ‘gov_consumption’ drawn from World Bank national accounts (post_registration.json → outcome description).
• Includes the full set of control variables used in the original long specification (replication_data/data.csv columns and analyze.R lines 14–23).
qualification.deviation_from_original:
• Original paper employed 74 countries covering WVS waves up to 2005 (post_registration.json → data.wave_or_subset); the replication file covers 31 countries observed in 2010 using later WVS waves 5–7 (replication_data/data.csv, variable ‘wave’ summary).
• Original analyses split the sample by Polity score; the replication sample contains only strong democracies (variable ‘democ’ min = 9, max = 10), creating a substantively new, restricted sample.

data_plan.notes: All variables are already aggregated; no respondent-level data are available. Year is constant (2010) so time dummies are unnecessary. The code offers an option to drop Wave 7 observations to mirror robustness checks.

planned_method.steps:
1. Load replication_data/data.csv.
2. (Optional) Drop countries whose latest WVS wave is 7 (flag drop_wave_7=True).
3. Random-shuffle variables for a test run (mode='test') to verify pipeline integrity.
4. Estimate the OLS 'long' specification on the real data with heteroskedasticity-robust (HC1) standard errors.
5. Save coefficient table for each run to /app/data/replication_data/output/.
planned_method.models: Cross-sectional OLS with HC1 robust covariance (equivalent to STATA robust).
planned_method.outcome_variable: gov_consumption – government final consumption expenditure as % of total consumption.
planned_method.control_variables: Regional dummies (africa, laam, asiae); colonial-origin dummies (col_uka, col_espa, col_otha); institutional dummies (federal, oecd); log_gdp_per_capita; trade_share; demographic structure (age_15_64, age_65_plus).

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: β coefficient on sd_gov in the long specification.
planned_estimation_and_test.test: Two-sided t-test using HC1 standard error.

planned_method.inference_criteria: Result supports hypothesis if β(sd_gov) is negative and statistically significant at α = 0.05.

files.replication_data/analyze_py.py: Python rewrite of the original analyze.R script. Loads data.csv, optionally drops Wave 7 observations, runs test and real analyses, estimates OLS with HC1 robust SEs, and writes results to CSV files in replication_data/output/.

codebase.notes: All I/O paths are relative to /app/data. The script seeds the permutation with NumPy’s default_rng(2020) to replicate the original R set.seed.

analysis.instructions:
Inside the container, run:  python /app/data/original/17/0203_python_o3/replication_data/analyze_py.py
The script automatically executes all four runs (test/real × drop/keep wave 7). The primary replication result is in output/real_drop_7.csv (and real_keep_7.csv for robustness).
analysis.comparison_metrics: Compare the sign, magnitude, and p-value of β(sd_gov) to the original coefficient −18.73 (SE = 4.79, p = .01). Key metrics: coefficient value, HC1 SE, p-value, and R².
